Dear Mr. Watkins, Jr.:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (989) 758-2717.

ALLEGATION: (1) It is alleged that the agency allowed visits to occur with
the foster child and biological father when they should not have occurred.
(2) It is alleged that the agency did not respond to an emergency as outlined
in their on-call policy. (3) It is alleged that the agency did not cooperate with
CPS as outlined in the agency policy.
INVESTIGATION:
The following documents were reviewed throughout the course of the investigation:
 Worker Contact and Monitoring Policy
 Physical and Mental Healthcare Policy
 New Light Incident Report (3)
 Safety Plan dated 10/23/20
 Social Work Contacts
 Order After Dispositional Review/Permanency Planning Hearing dated 10/2/20
 CPS Report Case 1996282770
3

I interviewed Chief Administrator 1 and Program Manager 1. Allegations and
documentation for this investigation were discussed.
Due to three separate allegations, each one will be addressed individually:
Allegation (1) It is alleged that the agency allowed visits to occur with the foster
child and biological father when they should not have occurred.
On 12/10/20, I interviewed Complainant 1. Complainant 1 reported the biological father
had a warrant for his arrest and that visits should never have taken place between
Foster Child 1 and Parent 1.
I reviewed an Order After Dispositional Review/Permanency Planning Hearing
dated 10/2/20. Parenting time is marked as unsupervised and “The department has the
discretion to allow unsupervised or supervised parenting time by its designee”.
The court order stated:
The child has been in foster care for 15 months of the most recent 22 months
and the agency should not initiate proceedings to terminate the parental rights to
the children for the following compelling reasons: Father was released from
prison and relocated to the Grand Rapids, Michigan area. He has a job and there
is the potential for the children to be placed with his relative in Grand Rapids.
This is a home he could move into with the girls until such a time as he could find
his own place. He has had seven extended visits with the girls and they look
forward to seeing him…Father is making progress towards reunification and
additional time is needed, as services were difficult to obtain due to pandemic.
I reviewed the following parenting time case notes:
Video Conference
6/11/20: visit was described as “good”

I interviewed Foster Care Worker 1 on 1/26/21 via telephone. Foster Care Worker 1
reported there were already successful visits made. Foster Care Worker 1 reported he
had just contacted Parent 1’s parole officer on 10/23/20 and Parent 1 was completing
his parole as required. Foster Care Worker 1 reported he contacted the parole officer on
10/15/20 and left a voicemail. The parole officer was changing, and he needed to know
who the new parole officer would be. Foster Care Worker 1 reported he spoke to Parent
1’s therapist on 10/22/20 to check on Parent 1’s status for continuation of visits. Foster
Care Worker 1 reported the therapist continued to support visits.
I reviewed case notes from Foster Care Worker 1 to Parole officer concerning
updates. Foster Care Worker 1 contacted the parole office on 9/23/20 and 10/15/20.
I reviewed a Safety Plan dated 10/23/20. The safety plan outlined substance free
lifestyle during overnight visits, contact case manager in emergencies, no use of
corporal punishment, and maintain safety of children while in care. This safety plan was
discussed with Foster Child 1 and Parent 1.
Allegation (2) It is alleged that the agency did not respond to an emergency as
outlined in their on-call policy.
On 12/10/20, I interviewed Complainant 1. Complainant 1 reported Foster Child 1 was
visiting her Parent 1 for a home pass. During that home pass, Parent 1 became
intoxicated and physically abused Foster Child 1. Complainant 1 reported Foster Care
Worker 1 was called by the on-call department of New Light agency due to issues
during the visit. Foster Care Worker 1 then called Foster Child 1 and conversed with
her. Due to the ongoing issues with Foster Child 1 and Parent 1, Foster Child 1 left and
went to a hotel with her aunt. Parent 1 was to remain in the home. This occurred on
10/31/20 at 4:38pm. Around 8:05pm, the on-call worker for New Light agency contacted
Foster Child 1 to ensure she was safe. Complainant 1 reported that Foster Child 1
reported she was safe. Complainant 1 reported that at 9:23pm, the on-call worker
received a phone call from Foster Child 1 crying and asking to be picked up from her
visit. Complainant 1 reported that the police and child protection services went out to the
hotel due to Foster Child 1 calling the police after she was choked and punched by
5

Parent 1. Parent 1 had not remained in his home. Instead, he came to the hotel where
Foster Child 1 was staying. Complainant 1 reported that the on-call worker was unable
to get a hold of Foster Care Worker 1 to pick up Foster Child 1. The police took Foster
Child 1 to an aunt’s house. Complainant 1 reported at 10:48pm the on-call worker was
able to reach Foster Care Worker 1 and they were going to pick up Foster Child 1 and
take her from her aunt’s house to the foster home.
I reviewed the Worker Contact and Monitoring Policy. The policy only addressed
missing person protocol. It did not address specific procedures related to on-call general
emergencies.
I reviewed the Physical and Mental Health Policy. The policy only addressed medical
emergencies and on-call interaction. It did not address specific procedures to on-call
general emergencies.
I interviewed Licensing Worker 1 on 1/26/21, via telephone. Licensing Worker 1
reported around 4pm on 10/31/20, Foster Child 1 texted her for Foster Worker 1’s
phone number. Foster Child 1 reported she wanted Foster Care Worker 1 to come pick
her up, but would not give a reason. Licensing Worker 1 called Foster Care Worker 1
and On-Call Worker 1 to relay message. Licensing Worker 1 received a phone call from
Foster Care Worker 1 updating her that Foster Child 1 was okay and that biological
parent and Foster Child 1 were going to separate for a while to deescalate. Around
8:00pm, Foster Care Worker 1 contacted Licensing Worker 1 because he could not get
a hold of Foster Child 1 and wanted to check up on her. Licensing Worker 1 reported
Foster Care Worker 1 asked her to text Foster Child 1 to determine her wellbeing.
Licensing Worker 1 reported she texted Foster Child 1 and Foster Child 1 reported she
was doing ok. Licensing Worker 1 reported she received a phone call around 9:30pm
from Foster Child 1. Foster Child 1 was crying and there was a police office at the hotel
with them. Licensing Worker 1 reported the neither the foster care workers or licensing
workers are mandated to work on the weekends. Licensing Worker 1 reported they
rotate working as the on- call worker. Licensing Worker 1 reported it is the on- call
worker’s role to be available 24/7 and to connect the emergency with the right support
personnel. Those supports could be police, CPS, medical, or New Light’s supervisor.
I interviewed Foster Care Worker 1 on 1/26/21 via telephone. Foster Care Worker 1
reported visits were going well with the children. At 4pm on 10/31/20, he received a
phone call from the Parent 1. He was upset due to an argument he had with Foster
Child 1 and did not know what to do. Foster Worker 1 reported he talked to him and
helped him with different parenting ideas. Foster Care Worker 1 discussed separating
until they were both clam and then Foster Care Worker 1 would be there in the morning.
Foster Care Worker 1 reported Parent 1 was deescalated when they hung up the
phone. Foster Care Worker 1 reported he spoke to Foster Child 1 at 4:35pm and she
reported she was ok. At 7:00pm, Foster Care Worker 1 reported Foster Child 1 went to
a hotel with her aunt and cousins to hang out. At 8:00pm Foster Care Worker 1 asked
Licensing Worker 1 to check on Foster Child 1 to make sure she arrived at the hotel.
After 8:00pm, Foster Worker 1 received a text from Foster Child 1. The text contained a
6

video of Parent 1 drinking. Foster Care Worker 1 reported around 8:30 he received a
phone call from the police reporting their involvement with Foster Child 1. Foster Care
Worker 1 reported he went with his supervisor to pick Foster Child 1 up.
I reviewed incident reports from Licensing Worker 1, Foster Care Worker 1, and On Call
Worker 1. All incident reports are congruent with the events described.
Allegation (3) (1) It is alleged that the agency did not cooperate with CPS as
outlined in the agency policy.
Complainant 1 reported New Light did not cooperate with the Maltreatment in Care
investigation initiated on 10/31/20. Complainant 1 reported they did not provide them
with phone calls or information concerning the aunt of the Foster Child 1.
I requested the New Light policy pertaining to 1975 PA 238. Program Manager 1
reported they do not have a policy outlining this.
I reviewed CPS Report Case 1996282770. Case notes indicate successful contact was
made to New Light on the following dates:
11/2/20: Interview with Foster Care Worker 1
11/3/20: Email from Foster Care Worker 1 to MIC providing requested information.
11/13/20: Successful phone contact to Foster Care Worker 1
11/16/20: Successful phone contact to Foster Care Worker 1
11/17/20: Foster Care Worker 1 and Program Manager 1 were present for disposition
conference
11/19/20: Successful phone contact with Foster Care Worker 1
I interviewed Foster Care Worker 1 and Program Manager1. Both reported cooperating
with MIC and providing information that was requested.
Program Manager 1 reported during a Child Stat review on 1/6/21, MIC did not have the
same amount of information that the agency had when presenting to the review board.
Program Manager 1 reported this was unsettling to the review board. This difference
was due to the agency supervising the case and being apart of all aspects of the case.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all of the following:
(e) Staff responsibilities.
ANALYSIS: The agency does have polices surrounding the on call worker,
but these policies lack general procedures and protocols for the
on call worker to follow.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12214 Compliance with 1975 PA 238.
An agency shall develop a written plan and implement the
plan to assure compliance with 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621,
and known as the child protection law.
ANALYSIS:  The agency cooperated with an ongoing investigation
conducted by child protective services. Case notes in
report 1996282770 verify this as well as interviews with
New Light.
 The agency does not have a current written plan for the
child protection law.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(a) A plan of visitation for each child in foster care
consistent with the child's service plans, as required by R
400.12419 and R 400.12420 to assure the safety and well
being of the child.
ANALYSIS:  The agency was court ordered to continue supervised
and unsupervised visits at their discretion.
 There were multiple successful visits, supervised and
unsupervised.
 A Safety Plan was in place.
 The agency contacted the Parole Officer of Parent 1 and
the therapist of Parent 1 for updates. The agency was
consistent with the visitation plan for reunification.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
A. It is recommended that the license remain unchanged.
